item.title: Prelim: Risk Sensitive Utility
item.description: Risk sensitivity is relative to the idea of utility. The value of a sum of money \(z\) to a decision maker may not be proportional to \(z\) itself but may be some general increasing function \(\mathsf{U}(z)\), known as the utility function. For example, in the example on optimal gambling considered earlier, we had assumed that the utility for wealth \(z\) is \(\log z\). If a decision maker has utility function \(\mathsf{U}\), then the value of a random outcome \(Z\) will be defined by the expected utility \(\EXP[\mathsf{U}(Z)]\).

Upon choosing the action \(u\), the decision maker incurs a cost \(c(u)\). What action should the decision maker pick to minimize the cost? item.title: Example: The Newsvendor Problem
item.description: Image credit: https://americangallery.wordpress.com/category/cafferty-james-h/ TL;DR The newsvendor problem is a simple model of stochastic optimization problem where a decision has to be made when there is uncertainty about the outcome. It also shows that for some stochastic optimization problems it is possible to obtain the qualitative properties of the nature of optimal solution. Each morning, a newsvendor has to decide how many newspapers to buy before knowing the demand during the day.
